page.title: 08OLD BUILDINGS IN BENTHAM
page.content: Saint John the Baptist, Low Bentham, is very old being mentioned in the Domesday Book. Part of a Saxon crucifix can be seen. The Rectors go back to 1300. The oldest part of the tower was once used as a lookout post in the 15th Century. The church was rebuilt in 1340 after being destroyed by Scots and rebuilt again in the 19th Century. Several Plague Stones are in local walls indicating that Bentham had the Plague. There is an example shaped like a well in the right hand side of Burton Rd, Low Bentham. There are many 17th Century farms, cottages and houses. Stonegate House dates back to 1600. The farm at Kirkbeck has the inscription "16XA76" over the door. Bentham Old Hall, recently restored, was a large farmhouse. The old beams, thick walls and stone flags can still be seen.
